content: The "Space Leadership Preservation Act of 2012" may be cited as such. It pertains to the Administrator and Deputy Administrator positions. Section 20111 of title 51, United States Code is amended to establish a 10-year term for the Administrator appointed by the President from among the Board of Directors nominations. The President appoints the Administrator from nominees provided by the Board of Directors within 3 months. The current Administrator can continue until the new one is confirmed by the Senate. The amendment establishes a 10-year term for the Administrator appointed by the President. The President appoints the Deputy Administrator from nominees provided by the Board of Directors. The President appoints the Deputy Administrator from nominees provided by the Board of Directors. The Space Leadership Preservation Act of 2012 establishes a Board of Directors for NASA with 11 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives. The Space Leadership Preservation Act of 2012 establishes a Board of Directors for NASA with 11 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives. The Board includes members appointed by the minority leader of the House of Representatives and qualifications for Board members include being former astronauts, scientists, engineers, and leaders in various scientific disciplines related to space and aeronautics. The Board of Directors for NASA consists of 11 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives. Board members must be former astronauts, scientists, engineers, or leaders in scientific disciplines related to space and aeronautics. Members cannot be employed by organizations with NASA contracts, and terms last for 3 years, with a maximum of 12 consecutive years of service. The Board of Directors for NASA consists of 11 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives, who must have backgrounds in space and aeronautics. Members serve 3-year terms, with a maximum of 12 consecutive years. After 12 years, a member is ineligible for reappointment for 2 years. Board members receive travel expenses and meet quarterly, with additional meetings as needed. The Chairman and Vice Chairman are elected at each first quarter meeting. The Vice Chairman of the Board is elected at the first quarter meeting in even-numbered years and assumes the Chairman's duties in their absence. If a vacancy occurs in either position, the Board will elect a member to fill it. The Board may appoint professional staff, technical personnel, and support staff as needed, with appointments made by the Chairman and approved by the Board. The Board is authorized to establish special commissions and appoint committees to assist in exercising its powers and functions under this section. The Board is required to submit a proposed budget for NASA to the President and relevant congressional committees by November 15 each year. The budget must align with the purpose of NASA and be based on professional judgment and recommendations from experts. The Board must submit a proposed budget for NASA to the President and congressional committees by November 15 each year, based on recommendations from technical experts and National Research Council decadal surveys. The Board also provides a list of nominees for administrator, deputy administrator, and chief financial officer to the President. The Board is required to provide lists of nominees for the positions of Administrator, Deputy Administrator, and Chief Financial Officer to the President. The first set of nominees must be submitted within 15 months of the enactment of the Space Leadership Preservation Act of 2012. Additionally, the Board is responsible for submitting an annual infrastructure, capabilities, and workforce assessment report. The Board is mandated to provide an annual report assessing the status of US spaceflight infrastructure, unique capabilities, and workforce health. The report should highlight concerns, capability gaps compared to foreign counterparts, and recommendations for strengthening US capabilities and workforce. The Board is required to provide an annual report on US spaceflight infrastructure, capabilities, and workforce. Additionally, it must conduct a quadrennial review of current space programs and future exploration vision, and can recommend the removal of the administrator for cause. The Board can recommend the removal of the Administrator for cause, and portions of budget meetings may be closed to the public until the budget proposal is submitted to the President and Congress. Members of the Board must file financial disclosure reports, which are confidential and exempt from public disclosure laws. The Board of Directors' budget proposal must be included in the President's proposed budget, with a detailed justification for any differences. The proposed budget by the Board of Directors must adhere to specific elements outlined in the code. Additionally, there are provisions for long-term contracting. The section 20142 of title 51, United States Code, is amended to include long term contracting for rocket propulsion systems, space transportation vehicles, payloads, and related services. Launch services are now referred to as goods and services provided under contracts.
